summary: lol at Arya fans calling Sansa useless.Sansa work hard to get back Winterfell. She ruled Winterfell and North and preparing for...
question: lol at Arya fans calling Sansa useless.Sansa work hard to get back Winterfell. She ruled Winterfell and North and preparing for winter and war. What exactly is Arya contribution? The only thing she did was trained herself with Brienne, threatened Sansa, and giving unnecessary problems to Sansa, while there are so many works still left for Sansa to do. If Arya is that useful, instead of degraded, attacked, and make Sansa's life harder for no reason, she can actually help lessen Sansa works.
answer:
Book!Arya is much better in that she actually does gain some useful skills and experiences (languages, leadership, understanding class issues she can probably improve with her status and such) and will most likely actually do something with her knowledge and training, but yeah, fans can shout “stick um wif da pointy end!” as their fan battle cry but that isn’t exactly going to help settle land disputes, work out an alliance with other realms, store food for hard seasons, etc. AKA all the stuff Sansa’s either done or will have to do as Lady of Winterfell.

Show!Arya has done absolutely nothing to help her own family (except carry out Petyr’s sentence I guess). She’s supposed to not be “useless” like SaLsA is, she’s supposed to be loyal to a fault towards her House, she’s supposed to be smarter and more resourceful- so when is she actually going to act like it?

Sansa and Jon have done the hard work. Show!Arya is basically that one relative who never spends any time with her family cuz she’d rather go out causing trouble with her friends, but will come once a year to Christmas for a free meal she didn’t help make and start drama with the people she doesn’t like thinking she can because daddy let her get away with stuff growing up.

summary:
When Cora’s family is killed, she flees to Winterfell hoping
to find safety there, having heard that Lady Sansa has returned...
caption: When Cora’s family is killed, she flees to Winterfell hoping to find safety there, having heard that Lady Sansa has returned home. What she’s not expecting is the feeling of relief at seeing her old friend alive after years of worrying for her safety. Together, they do what they can to fight against anyone that wishes to do them and their people harm. Along the way they learn that while they’ve lost a lot, they still have each other. And that together, they are stronger than anyone realizes.

summary: If the first ep of season 8 airs and all of a sudden there's a group of men from the Vale marching to Winterfell, when they...
question: If the first ep of season 8 airs and all of a sudden there's a group of men from the Vale marching to Winterfell, when they arrive, a young, handsome man introduces himself to the gatekeeper, he's like "I'm Lord Harrold Hardyng, i bring recluits and food for the Lady of Winterfell"  What would you do? xD
answer: I would not be ready for that kind of power move. D&D aren’t powerful enough to do something like that. However, if it happened, I would just die of happiness because it’s legitimately all I wanted in life. Like just imagine the six-episode romance in which we see Sansa end up with someone who appreciates her and recognizes her for the intelligent, capable young woman that she is. All the witty lines they would share, they would have to dance together too because that’s their brand, Sansa finally being able to have true love in her life, and just all of it would be great. The best part of that happening would be that it would mean that Sansa and Harry will more likely end up together in the books as well. However this time it wouldn’t be a six-episode romance, but two-books worth of perfection. I’m sold on the idea already.

title: Six Sentence Sunday
body:
Sansa stared at her hands on her lap. The silence was deafening.

Sandor shifted, his sword clanking faintly against the floorboards.

“Are you mad, girl? What is this foolishness? If this is a new game, it has to fucking stop.”

summary: While the iron throne will probably be destroyed, but who do you think would be the best ruler on it?
question: While the iron throne will probably be destroyed, but who do you think would be the best ruler on it?
answer:
Right now Sansa. Cersei’s pretty competent too. Besides blowing up the Sept to kill her enemies, she hasn’t lived up to the Mad Queen title people have given her. @gotgifsandmusings has talked about how for seasons Cersei on the show has been strangely unproblematic. She says shit but her actions are reasonable. Even the Margaery stuff, I mean Marg was in her 20s having sexual relations with a teenage boy and using that manipulate him. Cersei’s need to protect her son is justified compared to the books. 

So if Cersei is losing the throne, I want Sansa on it. Truthfully I’ll be happy when that thing is destroyed.

summary: Why do you think about the leak script? And all this Arya and Sansa horror plot
question: Why do you think about the leak script? And all this Arya and Sansa horror plot
answer: First of all I’m not going to trust the interpretations of Dany stan. At all. I know for a fact that D&D don’t write Dany like some super amazing comic book hero type saviour. Second of all I know D&D write the script with the audience’s POV in mind so the actors have to rely on the directors which is Maisie acted Arya like a B movie horror villain. Finally the last season aired more than a year ago and in it Arya comes off looking like a dumbass. If she was right the entire time they wouldn’t have bothered to show us Littlefinger’s face every time she fell for his dumbass plot.

summary: Who do you think Sansa will end up with?
question: Who do you think Sansa will end up with?
answer:
If I want to be completely honest, I really don’t know. That’s something I’m a bit worried about the next season, it’s what they are going to do with Sansa’s love life. I really want her to find happiness with someone who appreciates and respects her who is close to her age. That’s been a dream of hers since she was a child, and as much as people dismiss it, or portray it as a worthless dream, it’s completely valid for her. That being said, it’s not exactly something she had shown any interest in the past few seasons, mostly due to her traumatic rape. A lot of rape victims do start to trust less and see things much more pessimistically, which makes sense considering what they went through, but I think it’s rather important to start demystifying myths that rape victims are used goods incapable of finding love and being happy and wanting to enter relationships and get married. Life isn’t defined by that experience, and it would be really powerful to see Sansa manage to find happiness with someone after all she went through. She doesn’t need to end up with someone, but seeing as it is something that she had wanted for so long, I would love for her to get that happiness. 

Now, when it comes to who will sweep her off her feets, that’s another question entirely. I can say who that won’t be. Some people tried to push her into Ramsey and/or Petyr, but both of them are dead (thank god), so that’s not happening obviously. I really don’t think there are any chance that Sandor and Sansa will end up together. Not only did the show removed a big part of their scenes together, but Sansa has never mentioned him after he left King’s Landing and Sandor seems more defined by his travels with Arya than with all that happened with Sansa. So it does seem like they’re not going to enter that path, which I’m also very glad about. When it comes to Sansa and Tyrion, it doesn’t seem that likely either. According to interviews, Tyrion is in love with Daenerys (i never caught that while watching the show, which speaks volume on how badly they seem to handle these romances lately) and while he could move on from her and enter a relationship/marriage with Sansa, it really doesn’t seem likely. I also wouldn’t like it not only because of the age difference, but it would support the whole idea of Sansa not being mature enough as a child to appreciate Tyrion, but now that she’s an adult, she can realize how good he was to her and…well…I really don’t want that. As much as I like that ship, I don’t see any last minute Harry and Sansa ship happening anytime soon because they left his character out completely and never mentioned him. 

Then there’s Jonsa. Do I ship it? No, I don’t, but I don’t have any problems with it happening because that relationship would not only give Sansa what she wants but is one where there isn’t a wide age difference, and isn’t toxic/abusive. It could very much happen but I wouldn’t bet any money on it. In the original outline, Jon’s sister ended up running to the wall, and they ended up getting feelings for each other that they tried to ignore them until the reveal that they weren’t actually siblings. GRRM could have very much swapped Arya with Sansa as being that sister seeing as his plans for the both of them have completely changed. There’s also multiple theories such as the Ashford Tourney one which makes it more likely, GRRM commenting on a Jonsa post in a interesting manner implying that there’s been a buildup for it in the text (there are multiple metas that elaborate on that buildup), there would be a lot of political advantageous to such a marriage, and you could link multiple romantic tropes to their scenes. However, while I do think that the Starks are going to prevail, the chance of that relationship happening is not very likely in my opinion. Honestly, we’ll just see when the Season happens.

A lot of rape victims do start to trust less and see things much more pessimistically, which makes sense considering what they went through, but I think it’s rather important to start demystifying myths that rape victims are used goods incapable of finding love and being happy and wanting to enter relationships and get married. Life isn’t defined by that experience, and it would be really powerful to see Sansa manage to find happiness with someone after all she went through. She doesn’t need to end up with someone, but seeing as it is something that she had wanted for so long, I would love for her to get that happiness. 

Now, when it comes to who will sweep her off her feets, that’s another question entirely. I can say who that won’t be. Some people tried to push her into Ramsey and/or Petyr, but both of them are dead (thank god), so that’s not happening obviously. I really don’t think there are any chance that Sandor and Sansa will end up together. Not only did the show removed a big part of their scenes together, but Sansa has never mentioned him after he left King’s Landing and Sandor seems more defined by his travels with Arya than with all that happened with Sansa. So it does seem like they’re not going to enter that path, which I’m also very glad about. When it comes to Sansa and Tyrion, it doesn’t seem that likely either. According to interviews, Tyrion is in love with Daenerys (i never caught that while watching the show, which speaks volume on how badly they seem to handle these romances lately) and while he could move on from her and enter a relationship/marriage with Sansa, it really doesn’t seem likely. I also wouldn’t like it not only because of the age difference, but it would support the whole idea of Sansa not being mature enough as a child to appreciate Tyrion, but now that she’s an adult, she can realize how good he was to her and…well…I really don’t want that. As much as I like that ship, I don’t see any last minute Harry and Sansa ship happening anytime soon because they left his character out completely and never mentioned him. 

Then there’s Jonsa. Do I ship it? No, I don’t, but I don’t have any problems with it happening because that relationship would not only give Sansa what she wants but is one where there isn’t a wide age difference, and isn’t toxic/abusive. It could very much happen but I wouldn’t bet any money on it. In the original outline, Jon’s sister ended up running to the wall, and they ended up getting feelings for each other that they tried to ignore them until the reveal that they weren’t actually siblings. GRRM could have very much swapped Arya with Sansa as being that sister seeing as his plans for the both of them have completely changed. There’s also multiple theories such as the Ashford Tourney one which makes it more likely, GRRM commenting on a Jonsa post in a interesting manner implying that there’s been a buildup for it in the text (there are multiple metas that elaborate on that buildup), there would be a lot of political advantageous to such a marriage, and you could link multiple romantic tropes to their scenes. However, while I do think that the Starks are going to prevail, the chance of that relationship happening is not very likely in my opinion. Honestly, we’ll just see when the Season happens.

tags: Why are the showrunners so biased against Jon?
Gosh are the GOT scripts incredibly anti-Stark
summary: Vanity Fair Game of Throne Scripts
title: Vanity Fair Game of Throne Scripts
body:
I haven’t had time to read the “scripts” and think that people are trying to deduce things based on Easter Eggs that don’t mean that much.  However, it does seem like the entire tone of the scripts, especially D&D juvenile asides, are anti-Stark and incredibly anti-Jon.  Does anyone have any insight into why the writers of the show hate the Starks and hate Jon as a character?  Is it just them tearing down the male characters to make Daenerys Targaryen look good?  Or is it something else?

I was aware how much the writers disliked Jon as a character based on how stupid they made in Season 6 and Season 7.  But even I was stunned by the amount of vitriol the writers direct toward the main heroes of the story in their scripts.  The writers’ weird, vitriolic biases against the Starks may end up really ruining the show even more than the fact that Martin will never finish the last two books.

tags: and a black chevrolet bel air
title: Six Sentence Sunday
body:
If I manage to write so much as 500 words during this busy week I will call myself lucky… Here’s something I wrote a while ago, from my WIP One Little Slip:

A minute later, we were in the car, a brand-new, black Chevrolet Bel Air, driving to the outskirts of San Diego where the old Pycelle lived. I offered Sansa a cigarette - which she refused - and I lit one for myself. As silence stretched I resisted the urge to turn on the car radio, imagining music would only give her another reason not to speak. And for a second I had the odd sensation my mind left my body and that I could see us from outside, through the windshield, as we were sitting side by side in the Chevrolet. I was driving my favorite car at the moment, the one that made my mouth water a little and never failed to bring a distorted smile on my half-burnt face when I had a chance to drive it; and next to me was the most beautiful girl I had ever seen, wearing a pretty white dress that looked ethereal under the artificial light of the streetlamps. My shoulders sagged anyway. There were blood stains on the pretty white dress and the girl had not spoken a word since I found her in the ladies’ room. 

Pictures: two stills from Double Indemnity (1944).

blog.description: Jenny. This blog consists mainly of Game of Thrones/A Song of Ice and Fire, with particular focus on Tyrion, but also among my favorites are Sansa, Cersei, Arya, and Brienne. I also occasionally post about video games or books or whatever else I find interesting.

summary: When dudes say that Sansa is annoying or that they hope horrible things happen to her I remember how the first time I read her...
body:
When dudes say that Sansa is annoying or that they hope horrible things happen to her I remember how the first time I read her chapters I was constantly terrified for her. What her chapters do really well is encapsulate the fear of assault that is in the back of every woman’s mind, so when men respond to that with annoyance and hate it does say something about their inability or unwillingness to empathize with women. Remember that post about the bank analogy that comes around every so often about how men do not understand why women are afraid of men unless it’s put in terms they explicitly identify with? One of the reasons Sansa gets so much hate is because she’s constantly under the threat of assault and men either can’t or don’t want to empathize with that.

That’s also the reason Sansa is getting less hate now that the show has “empowered” her (after fulfilling the wishes of everyone who wanted to see her be raped first, of course).

This is why the fandom needed to empathize with Sansa from the very beginning of the story regardless of how kind or empowered or good she was.

Of course, the fear of assault is present in the storylines of other characters, too (and I could talk for days about how this is overlooked or outright disregarded in the narratives of girls or women who don’t fit idealized expectations of femininity, like Arya or Dany, or even in Tyrion’s narrative, because he’s a disabled adult man. GRRM sets us up to constantly fear for Sansa’s sexual purity because she’s an idealized ingenue archetype, and there is misogyny in that narrative. I also think GRRM himself does not treat the characters fairly in this respect. I think he treats Arya like she’ll be fine no matter how many men leer at her because she’s spunky and unfeminine and not the type of girl we are supposed to worry about that happening to.) But that visceral fear is so present in nearly every aspect of Sansa’s narrative and women understand that much better than men do.

tags: she and arya are my two faves no question
summary: Sansa is my favorite character from GoT/ASoIaF, and she deserves so much better, but ESPECIALLY in the books. Long live the Lady...
question: Sansa is my favorite character from GoT/ASoIaF, and she deserves so much better, but ESPECIALLY in the books. Long live the Lady of Winterfell!
answer:
Me every time the SANSA chapter heading comes up in my AS0IAF book or her face pops up on my screen or dash:

Seriously, though! What a wonderful character. Last week I saw someone saying that Sansa Stark season 1-3 is the worst character on television and I was like, bitch where? Sophie Turner’s amazing acting aside, I guess if you have something against the most introspective, intelligent, kindest character on the show then maybe that makes sense? It’s really not a coincidence that a lot of people only started liking show!Sansa after she started becoming more toxically masculine/violent. It’s not a coincidence that people consider her books/seasons 1-3 arcs to be static and her character to be “weak” even though that’s demonstrably untrue. I have zero doubt in my mind that if Sansa was a boy she would be a fan favorite. People love to forget how AGOT-ASOS Jon, Theon, and Robb each fall into some of the whiniest and most stereotypical (and in Theon’s case, disgusting imo) teenage boy tropes I’ve ever had the misfortune to read. And yet somehow they’re not held accountable for what happened to the Starks. People don’t hate them with a burning passion and write essays on why they owe everyone an apology and deserve what they got. In fact, people bend over backward to sympathize with them and justify all the astronomically stupid mistakes they’ve made.

I admire Sansa so much for going through all she’s been through without murdering every single person around her. Both within the books and in fandom, Sansa is just a character who really needs someone to be on her side. She rarely gets any validation or support from any other character without an ulterior motive. Maybe the last time someone helped her out of their own good will and for her sole benefit was back when Ned and Cat were still alive. So many things that she can’t understand are constantly happening to and around her, and people always try to take advantage of that due to her age and appearance. She’s perhaps the kindest character in the entire series, the most genuine and yet the most lacking of love, but everyone wants to use her for optics or money. She’s so underrated because her interests and skills are highly associated with femininity. Everyone loves to ignore the fact that it takes a special kind of person to survive five years of a hostage situation and the deaths of multiple family members. I’ll fight anyone who tries to argue against that and I’ll defend Sansa to my death.

trail.content_raw:
Me every time the SANSA chapter heading comes up in my AS0IAF book or her face pops up on my screen or dash:

Seriously, though! What a wonderful character. Last week I saw someone saying that Sansa Stark season 1-3 is the worst character on television and I was like, bitch where? Sophie Turner’s amazing acting aside, I guess if you have something against the most introspective, intelligent, kindest character on the show then maybe that makes sense? It’s really not a coincidence that a lot of people only started liking show!Sansa after she started becoming more toxically masculine/violent. It’s not a coincidence that people consider her books/seasons 1-3 arcs to be static and her character to be “weak” even though that’s demonstrably untrue. I have zero doubt in my mind that if Sansa was a boy she would be a fan favorite. People love to forget how AGOT-ASOS Jon, Theon, and Robb each fall into some of the whiniest and most stereotypical (and in Theon’s case, disgusting imo) teenage boy tropes I’ve ever had the misfortune to read. And yet somehow they’re not held accountable for what happened to the Starks. People don’t hate them with a burning passion and write essays on why they owe everyone an apology and deserve what they got. In fact, people bend over backward to sympathize with them and justify all the astronomically stupid mistakes they’ve made.

I admire Sansa so much for going through all she’s been through without murdering every single person around her. Both within the books and in fandom, Sansa is just a character who really needs someone to be on her side. She rarely gets any validation or support from any other character without an ulterior motive. Maybe the last time someone helped her out of their own good will and for her sole benefit was back when Ned and Cat were still alive. So many things that she can’t understand are constantly happening to and around her, and people always try to take advantage of that due to her age and appearance. blog.title: FedonCiadale
blog.description: Fantasy aficionado since I read Tolkien in my teenage years. I still love Tolkien but I am also into other works. I love ASOIAF (books) and GoT (Show). I also like Brandon Sanderson, Lois McMaster Bujold, in short in my free time it's fantasy...Header by courtesy of ragekitn!

tags: Sansa haters should just admit they don't support House Stark
summary: I've been subscribed to freefolk for news for less than a week and every day I am bombarded with blatant Sansa hate on many...
question: I've been subscribed to freefolk for news for less than a week and every day I am bombarded with blatant Sansa hate on many different posts. Is Tumblr the only place that respects Sansa as a character? We really are a minority.
answer:
Dear nonny,

It seems this is a good time to answer your post, since we were reminded by some of the more vocal even on tumblr how ‘awful’ Sansa is. It seems even here we do have to fight for the ‘Sansa Stark defence squad’ once in a while.

I must admit that I myself have not always loved Sansa. I liked Jon from the start and I really related to Arya - coming from a similar situation like Arya myself. I do have an older sister who is traditionally feminine and I wanted to run with the boys and played soccer with my brother. And it took me a while to re-evaluate Sansa. I sort of pitied her ever since Ned died and read her chapters with greater interest until I reached the Battle of the Blackwater. The scene with the Hound really struck a cord in me. Sansa was threatened by a big, dangerous man and her resilience in this situation, the fact that she sang, but not the song he wanted and that the ‘magic’ of her plead for mercy was so strong that a brutal man relented from brutally abducting and maybe raping her had me moved to tears. Ever since then I’ve been on Sansa’s side. It is such a well written scene! -

(Just for the record : I don’t ship SanSan, I’ve never shipped it, I have pity with the Hound but I think his role is to die as a real knight in defence of the weak. The purpose of this scene was not romantic but to show the power of Sansa’s soft ‘magic’, the singing that is parallel to Tolkien’s Luthien - as I explained in my Beren and Luthien meta (link to the third part here) months before someone stole this [sry for the deviation… Still pissed the other side of the fandom takes our things minus the Jonsa parts and tries to pimp their own mediocre takes, althought others were done much more badly than me]).

I may not have liked Sansa from the beginning but since I’ve always been House Stark, Sansa did have a small part in my heart all the time. Because I rooted for all the Starks. And this is why I don’t get the hate Sansa gets from some Arya fans. I mean if you like Arya, you presumably like House Stark, and House Stark includes Sansa - who identifies internally as a Stark ever since her father died. She might be your least favourite Stark but why deny that she is one? I mean I sort of get Da€nerys fans who don’t like Sansa - she is the daughter of one of the usurper’s dogs after all - but anyone who is on Team House Stark and wishes Sansa dead should get their membership card revoked.

So, some (not all of course) of Arya’s fans want things Arya herself would never want: being Queen, Sansa dead etc. and I while do know that things can be read differently, how they come to the idea that the sisters genuinely hate each other is beyond me.

The VF article has not improved the bad takes on Sansa. People seem not to understand, that what we actually see on screen and what the actors are told is more relevant than something that was pinned down in advance, where the writers very clearly wrote down what they want to be the General audience’s take in that situation. So, Maisie Wiliams telling that she was directed to play the “villain” is meaningless, while a part from the script where they want to dupe the audience into believing in Starkbowl is gospel.

And it is always like that. I do think that by now, Sansa could be a veritable angel (which she is not) and they would still find something to blame on her. And they contradict themselves as well: Sansa is stupid and naiv and a slow learner but she is also this deft manipulator without scruples (manipulating the Northern Lords into liking her, while she is working to depose Jon). You know the woman who said ‘Only a fool trusts Littlefinger’ (in a setting where she has no reason to lie), somehow trusts Littlefinger? The woman who declines to be declared queen instead of the absent Jon is working against him (because she was waiting for a better moment to be declared queen or what?). The woman who cares for the armour and the food of her people is a self-centred entitled narcist… And you know, even with the subpar writing of season 7, it should be even possible to think that Sansa did not trust Littlefinger and was still worried about what Arya would do. It is - surprise, surprise - quite possible not to trust someone and still allow for that person to have insight and to learn from them, and it is also possible to mistrust someone you love and be worried about what your impulsive little sister might do, without outright planning to kill her. Because you want to hold everything together in the face of a very dangerous outward threat and the absence of the king, it is only sensible to have an eye on a very dangerous assassin sister who threatened to take over your own face….

I guess the reason Sansa hate is so common in this fandom is because GRRM did a really bold thing. He introduced Sansa from the PoV of a little sister whose issues with self-confidence has a lot to do with her older sister (without the older sister rubbing this in I might add - I don’t want to elaborate here, but if you read closely it is quite clear, that Sansa covers for her sister and the ‘bullying’ that some of the fans blame on her is simply not there). Now our first impression is the beautiful, girly, superficial girl who is a pain in the ass to every girl who does not adhere to society’s strict expectations towards girls, who is not beautiful or does not feel beautiful and is a tomboy. How this trope usually works is that the ‘bullied’ girl develops from an ugly duck to a beautiful swan, the ‘mean’ girl falls on hard times because she misjudged people because of her superficiality and is finally punished. Cinderella and her step-sisters show her faces here…

I do think that this is the reason why many, many people in the fandom still expect Sansa to die and to be punished, and to be in general a mean character. People expect her to become the mean machinator at Littlefinger’s side and falling beside him, they expect her to die or to become a ‘fallen woman’ (ending up in a brothel or such, yikes)… And all because they fell for the PoV in AGOT and they feel for the trope that GRRM has set up and they probably fell for this picture of a ‘mean girl’ that has plagued their own high school days. (I give them some advice: They’ll never get beyond their own issues if they do not let go of their hatred of that mean high school girl and realise that life is not high school.)

What GRRM does, is to subvert this type: The ‘evil older stepsister’ is actually not evil (and never was), she learns from her mistakes and she has character development. But this is usually something that is a prerogative of male heroes. Female heroes may have a learning arc, but that is usually not set up as a character development arc as in overcoming some faults.

Fandom somehow has no problem with accepting Jaime’s redemption arc or Theon’s, but God forbid to accept character development that is contrary to tropes. Arya begins as a girl whose skills are not valued in her society and it is a quite common trope to have her acquiring more skills and possibly come out on top because of that. Da€nerys is the girl that starts as an absolute underdog and that accumulates power to set right the wrongs done to her. What fandom fails to realise is that Arya is so set on revenge that she has begun to follow a dark path (more so in the show than the books) and that Da€nerys acquires some traits of her abusers along the way to the top. Arya and Da€nerys also subvert tropes but people are blind to that, because theirs are tropes that make the underestimated girl a heroine in the end and they get high on that. They are lured by the tropes as well as the PoV traps. So, Sansa haters are stuck in the preconceptions they acquired while reading AGOT which leads them to grossly misread not only Sansa but others as well (the Hound as a good guy (???) and an important character (when he doesn’t even have a PoV), Arya as hating Sansa, Littlefinger as the master manipulator who’ll recruit Sansa for his cause)

There is also another reason for Sansa hate which has nothing to do with GRRM but with society. Girly girls are just not fashionable. It is cool to like the tomboy girls, the badass girls, the sassy girls, but not feminine girls - at least in FICTION. In reality this is much more complex. In my experience girly girls - at least after a phase of really irrational hatred during the teenage years, that most sensible people leave behind them - are not hated. This is connected to the overblown expectations people have in regard to women - not only men, but women as well. I would hesitate to call this internalised misogyny, I would rather call this internalised overblown expectations. A woman should be smart (but not so smart that she can outwit a man), she should be strong and badass and independent (but not too independent, she should need male validation after all), but she should also be beautiful and care for her beauty. A girl with a gun chasing villains? Wonderful! But are her legs hairless? Do her nails look good? Does she run in high heels? So, there are many men who would tell you they like badass woman but in reality? They’d rather not have a woman who doesn’t have time to don makeup, shave her legs and do her nails…. So, hating girly girls in fiction is easy: Men can pretend that they don’t care for girly girls and show how ‘advanced’ they are by rooting for the tomboy (who after all fits to their male ideals and stresses the idea that male actitivities are ‘better’) and women can hate on the girly girls, because either they’d rather not be like that (for whatever reason, one of them might be that they also adhere to the ideal that male activities are better) or because they feel the pressure to become girly to fit into society’s expectations that are there despite the fact that women are told at the same time, that being girly is lesser. Being frustrated with this kind of contradictory expectations might make you hate the girly girl type - I can understand that. When I was younger and more naive I did as well.

It’s a catch 22 really. And as long as people (men and women) won’t realise that feminism is not about all women becoming like men nor about looking down on women who feel comfortable with being a traditional woman and as long as these activities are seen as somehow being lesser we will have people who hate on fictional characters that do question their take on feminity. I have some issues with GRRM’s take on women - mostly because he ignores the importance of female friendships - but I certainly have no issues with the variety of women he describes, nor with the fact that he shows a kind of female strength that is so often ridiculed in fiction and in real world.

This was a long answer, but honestly, although I’m foremost a Jon Snow fan, this fandom has made me into a member of the Sansa Stark defence squad.

Thanks for the ask!

I do think that this is the reason why many, many people in the fandom still expect Sansa to die and to be punished, and to be in general a mean character. People expect her to become the mean machinator at Littlefinger’s side and falling beside him, they expect her to die or to become a ‘fallen woman’ (ending up in a brothel or such, yikes)… And all because they fell for the PoV in AGOT and they feel for the trope that GRRM has set up and they probably fell for this picture of a ‘mean girl’ that has plagued their own high school days. (I give them some advice: They’ll never get beyond their own issues if they do not let go of their hatred of that mean high school girl and realise that life is not high school.)

What GRRM does, is to subvert this type: The ‘evil older stepsister’ is actually not evil (and never was), she learns from her mistakes and she has character development. But this is usually something that is a prerogative of male heroes. Female heroes may have a learning arc, but that is usually not set up as a character development arc as in overcoming some faults.

Fandom somehow has no problem with accepting Jaime’s redemption arc or Theon’s, but God forbid to accept character development that is contrary to tropes. Arya begins as a girl whose skills are not valued in her society and it is a quite common trope to have her acquiring more skills and possibly come out on top because of that. Da€nerys is the girl that starts as an absolute underdog and that accumulates power to set right the wrongs done to her. What fandom fails to realise is that Arya is so set on revenge that she has begun to follow a dark path (more so in the show than the books) and that Da€nerys acquires some traits of her abusers along the way to the top. Arya and Da€nerys also subvert tropes but people are blind to that, because theirs are tropes that make the underestimated girl a heroine in the end and they get high on that. They are lured by the tropes as well as the PoV traps. So, Sansa haters are stuck in the preconceptions they acquired while reading AGOT which leads them to grossly misread not only Sansa but others as well (the Hound as a good guy (???) and an important character (when he doesn’t even have a PoV), Arya as hating Sansa, Littlefinger as the master manipulator who’ll recruit Sansa for his cause)

There is also another reason for Sansa hate which has nothing to do with GRRM but with society. Girly girls are just not fashionable. It is cool to like the tomboy girls, the badass girls, the sassy girls, but not feminine girls - at least in FICTION. In reality this is much more complex. In my experience girly girls - at least after a phase of really irrational hatred during the teenage years, that most sensible people leave behind them - are not hated. This is connected to the overblown expectations people have in regard to women - not only men, but women as well. I would hesitate to call this internalised misogyny, I would rather call this internalised overblown expectations. A woman should be smart (but not so smart that she can outwit a man), she should be strong and badass and independent (but not too independent, she should need male validation after all), but she should also be beautiful and care for her beauty. A girl with a gun chasing villains? Wonderful! But are her legs hairless? Do her nails look good? Does she run in high heels? So, there are many men who would tell you they like badass woman but in reality? They’d rather not have a woman who doesn’t have time to don makeup, shave her legs and do her nails…. So, hating girly girls in fiction is easy: Men can pretend that they don’t care for girly girls and show how ‘advanced’ they are by rooting for the tomboy (who after all fits to their male ideals and stresses the idea that male actitivities are ‘better’) and women can hate on the girly girls, because either they’d rather not be like that (for whatever reason, one of them might be that they also adhere to the ideal that male activities are better) or because they feel the pressure to become girly to fit into society’s expectations that are there despite the fact that women are told at the same time, that being girly is lesser. Being frustrated with this kind of contradictory expectations might make you hate the girly girl type - I can understand that. When I was younger and more naive I did as well.

It’s a catch 22 really. And as long as people (men and women) won’t realise that feminism is not about all women becoming like men nor about looking down on women who feel comfortable with being a traditional woman and as long as these activities are seen as somehow being lesser we will have people who hate on fictional characters that do question their take on feminity. I have some issues with GRRM’s take on women - mostly because he ignores the importance of female friendships - but I certainly have no issues with the variety of women he describes, nor with the fact that he shows a kind of female strength that is so often ridiculed in fiction and in real world.

This was a long answer, but honestly, although I’m foremost a Jon Snow fan, this fandom has made me into a member of the Sansa Stark defence squad.

Thanks for the ask!
trail.content:
Dear nonny,

It seems this is a good time to answer your post, since we were reminded by some of the more vocal even on tumblr how ‘awful’ Sansa is. It seems even here we do have to fight for the ‘Sansa Stark defence squad’ once in a while.

I must admit that I myself have not always loved Sansa. I liked Jon from the start and I really related to Arya - coming from a similar situation like Arya myself. I do have an older sister who is traditionally feminine and I wanted to run with the boys and played soccer with my brother. And it took me a while to re-evaluate Sansa. I sort of pitied her ever since Ned died and read her chapters with greater interest until I reached the Battle of the Blackwater. The scene with the Hound really struck a cord in me. Sansa was threatened by a big, dangerous man and her resilience in this situation, the fact that she sang, but not the song he wanted and that the ‘magic’ of her plead for mercy was so strong that a brutal man relented from brutally abducting and maybe raping her had me moved to tears. Ever since then I’ve been on Sansa’s side. It is such a well written scene! -

(Just for the record : I don’t ship SanSan, I’ve never shipped it, I have pity with the Hound but I think his role is to die as a real knight in defence of the weak. The purpose of this scene was not romantic but to show the power of Sansa’s soft ‘magic’, the singing that is parallel to Tolkien’s Luthien - as I explained in my Beren and Luthien meta (link to the third part here) months before someone stole this [sry for the deviation… Still pissed the other side of the fandom takes our things minus the Jonsa parts and tries to pimp their own mediocre takes, althought others were done much more badly than me]).

I may not have liked Sansa from the beginning but since I’ve always been House Stark, Sansa did have a small part in my heart all the time. Because I rooted for all the Starks. And this is why I don’t get the hate Sansa gets from some Arya fans. I mean if you like Arya, you presumably like House Stark, and House Stark includes Sansa - who identifies internally as a Stark ever since her father died. She might be your least favourite Stark but why deny that she is one? I mean I sort of get Da€nerys fans who don’t like Sansa - she is the daughter of one of the usurper’s dogs after all - but anyone who is on Team House Stark and wishes Sansa dead should get their membership card revoked.

So, some (not all of course) of Arya’s fans want things Arya herself would never want: being Queen, Sansa dead etc. and I while do know that things can be read differently, how they come to the idea that the sisters genuinely hate each other is beyond me.

The VF article has not improved the bad takes on Sansa. People seem not to understand, that what we actually see on screen and what the actors are told is more relevant than something that was pinned down in advance, where the writers very clearly wrote down what they want to be the General audience’s take in that situation. So, Maisie Wiliams telling that she was directed to play the “villain” is meaningless, while a part from the script where they want to dupe the audience into believing in Starkbowl is gospel.

And it is always like that. I do think that by now, Sansa could be a veritable angel (which she is not) and they would still find something to blame on her. And they contradict themselves as well: Sansa is stupid and naiv and a slow learner but she is also this deft manipulator without scruples (manipulating the Northern Lords into liking her, while she is working to depose Jon). You know the woman who said ‘Only a fool trusts Littlefinger’ (in a setting where she has no reason to lie), somehow trusts Littlefinger? The woman who declines to be declared queen instead of the absent Jon is working against him (because she was waiting for a better moment to be declared queen or what?). The woman who cares for the armour and the food of her people is a self-centred entitled narcist… And you know, even with the subpar writing of season 7, it should be even possible to think that Sansa did not trust Littlefinger and was still worried about what Arya would do. It is - surprise, surprise - quite possible not to trust someone and still allow for that person to have insight and to learn from them, and it is also possible to mistrust someone you love and be worried about what your impulsive little sister might do, without outright planning to kill her. Because you want to hold everything together in the face of a very dangerous outward threat and the absence of the king, it is only sensible to have an eye on a very dangerous assassin sister who threatened to take over your own face….

I guess the reason Sansa hate is so common in this fandom is because GRRM did a really bold thing. He introduced Sansa from the PoV of a little sister whose issues with self-confidence has a lot to do with her older sister (without the older sister rubbing this in I might add - I don’t want to elaborate here, but if you read closely it is quite clear, that Sansa covers for her sister and the ‘bullying’ that some of the fans blame on her is simply not there). Now our first impression is the beautiful, girly, superficial girl who is a pain in the ass to every girl who does not adhere to society’s strict expectations towards girls, who is not beautiful or does not feel beautiful and is a tomboy. How this trope usually works is that the ‘bullied’ girl develops from an ugly duck to a beautiful swan, the ‘mean’ girl falls on hard times because she misjudged people because of her superficiality and is finally punished. Cinderella and her step-sisters show her faces here…

summary: My friend doesn't watch Game of Thrones and I asked her to describe the characters:
body:
My friend doesn’t watch Game of Thrones and I asked her to describe the characters:

Arya: Baby girl, baby

Sansa: She has nice hair and relationship issues

Jon: Apparently, he knows nothing

Bran: Tiny

Rickon: The zig-zag man

Robb: Dead?

Theon: Robin Hood

Daenerys: The one that’s nice to look at

Viserys: Legolas

Khal Drogo: He looks like Aquaman

Jorah: He looks like a very tired dad

Cersei: That’s the bitch, right?

Jaime: Handicapped twin of the bitch

Tyrion: Oh, that’s Peter Dinklage

Joffrey: Dickhead

The Hound: Two-face but with Thor’s hair

Margaery: She’s ginger and pretty, I like her

Melisandre: Pretty scary witch lady

Stannis: He’s got that flaming sword, right?

Shireen: Tiny baby girl with velociraptor skin

Ygritte: Angry Merida that knows more than Jon Snow

Ramsay: The dude that’s pretty and scary

Night King: Elsa with freezer burn

summary:
Got S7!Arya: You want to know the real difference between you and me?
Sansa: Let me see... I know how to rule and you don't? Or,...
body:
Got S7!Arya: You want to know the real difference between you and me?

Sansa: Let me see… I know how to rule and you don’t? Or, I have class and you don’t? Take your pick.
